speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me a little bit about your mother's pregnancy with you? Did she experience any complications or issues during her pregnancy?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, Doctor. She just kind of went through it, you know? No one seemed to notice anything out of the ordinary until after I was born.

speaker: Doctor
text: How long did she carry you, and did she have any prenatal appointments that required her to be hospitalized or receive any special care?

speaker: Patient
text: I was born at term, and from what I've heard, she didn't really go to any prenatal appointments. I don't think she even knew she was supposed to be there.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your birth weight and length? Was it above or below average for a newborn of your gestational age?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm a bit light, actually. My birth weight was 3000 grams, and I'm about 46 centimeters long. My mom says I'm one of the smallest, but I don't really know what that means.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a look at your physical examination. Can you please turn your head to the right for me, so I can check your neck and throat?

speaker: Patient
text: I'll try my best. *turns head to the right* Is everything okay, Doctor?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me your tongue, please? And gently open your mouth so I can see the back of it?

speaker: Patient
text: *opens mouth* I don't know if I can do that, Doctor. It feels a little weird.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if you have noticed any breathing difficulties, such as fast breathing, or if you have a fever at all?



Please turn your head to the left now, so I can examine your neck and throat from that side.



Also, I'd like to see the back of your tongue again, but this time, I'd like you to stick out your tongue as far as you can.

speaker: Patient
text:
No, Doctor, I don't think I've ever had any trouble breathing. But I did have some trouble hearing when I was born, and the doctor said I need to get my hearing checked again soon.

*stretches neck to the left, trying to relax* I don't know if I can stick out my tongue all the way, but I'll try. *stretches tongue out as far as I can*

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you move your tongue to the left, so I can see the back of it better?



Also, I'd like to check your ears for any discharge or redness. Please tilt your head to the right, so I can see the back of your ear.

speaker: Patient
text: I'll try, Doctor. *tries to move tongue to the left*

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your birth weight and length? Did you have any immediate concerns or difficulties after birth, such as feeding or breathing issues?



REQUEST TEST: Blood_Sugar

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the birth process, specifically how quickly you were born and if there were any issues with your transition to the outside world after birth?



Also, can you move your tongue to the center of your mouth for me, so I can take a closer look at the uvula?



Is there anything you've noticed about your feeding, such as difficulty latching, spitting up, or having trouble burping?



Can you please lift your chin up for me, so I can examine your neck and throat area from a different angle?

speaker: Patient
text:
I don't really remember much about the birth process, Doctor. I think I came out pretty quickly, but my mom says she didn't feel like it was normal. I just kind of... felt the light, you know?

*tries to move tongue to the center of mouth* It feels a bit funny, but I'll try.

I don't really remember feeding, Doctor. I just kind of... sucked and it seemed to work. My mom says I didn't spit up much at all, but I did get a bit of gas sometimes.

*tries to lift chin up*

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you show me the back of your tongue again, and this time, gently curl it back towards the roof of your mouth for me?



Also, I'd like to take a closer look at the back of your throat, so please slowly swallow for me.

speaker: Patient
text:
I'll try to curl it back, Doctor. *tries to curl tongue back towards the roof of mouth* It feels a bit tight, though.

*swallows slowly*

I don't really remember what it was like when I was feeding, Doctor. It all just kinda happened. My mom says I seemed to latch on okay, but I don't really know what that means.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your feeding, such as difficulty latching, spitting up, or having trouble burping? 

Also, I'd like to examine the back of your throat more closely, so please take a deep breath in and slowly let it out, and then I'd like you to gargle with water for me.

speaker: Patient
text: I didn't really notice anything unusual about feeding, Doctor. It just kinda worked, you know? My mom says I didn't spit up much at all, but I did get a bit of gas sometimes.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your eyes now. Can you look up at me and then down at the floor, and then back up at me? I'm checking for any signs of strabismus or other eye abnormalities.

speaker: Patient
text: Can I just look at you for a second, Doctor?

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you look up at me and hold that position for a second, so I can observe your eyes more closely?



Also, I'd like to see your hands and feet, are they symmetrical and properly aligned?



Can you move your arms slightly, so I can examine your shoulders and upper back?



Can you tell me if you notice any sensations in your chest or abdomen, such as discomfort or tightness?



REQUEST TEST: Eye_Examination

text:
Can you look down at the floor and then up at me again, and this time, I'd like you to hold that position for a few seconds so I can observe your eyes more closely?



Also, can you please show me your hands and feet again, and this time, I'd like you to spread your fingers apart for me?

speaker: Patient
text:
I don't remember much about the pregnancy, Doctor. I think my mom just kind of went through it like you said. She didn't seem to have any problems, but after I was born, I did have some trouble hearing.

Can I just look down at the floor and then up at you again?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your birth process, specifically how quickly you were born and if there were any issues with your transition to the outside world after birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I came out pretty quickly, I think, but my mom says she didn't feel like it was normal. I just kind of... felt the light, you know? And after I was born, I didn't really cry much.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe your mother's prenatal care and any medications she took during her pregnancy?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think she got any prenatal care, Doctor. She just kind of... went through it.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your mother's prenatal care and any medications she took during her pregnancy? 

Did she follow any specific diet or lifestyle recommendations during her pregnancy, such as avoiding certain foods or exercising regularly?

speaker: Patient
text: No, Doctor. My mom didn't really do anything special with her diet or exercise during pregnancy. She just kind of... ate what she wanted and went about her daily life, I think.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to examine your chest and back a bit further. Can you please place your arms on your sides and lean forward slightly so I can check your heart and lungs?



Also, I'd like to ask, did your mother take any prenatal vitamins or supplements during her pregnancy?



Can you show me your feet again, and I'd like to check the soles of your feet for any unusual markings or coloration?



Also, I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Skin_Examination

text:

Also, can you show me the tops of your feet, are your toes webbed or are they normally spaced apart?

speaker: Patient
text: The soles of my feet are kinda... lighter, I think. They're not really pink like normal people's feet.
